Describe the vertical salinity distribution along a transect in the delta.

The vertical salinity distribution along a transect in the delta is characterized by an offshore buoyant plume, which is the result of buoyant inflow from riverine water entering the delta. The plume is delineated by an isohaline of 18 g/kg, which separates the buoyant water from the ambient seawater with salinity more than 20 g/kg. At the ebb tide, the isohalines are tilted and stratification is expected to occur at the end of the ebb stage. At the flood tide, the isohalines are pushed landward in order to destabilize stratification and develop a bottom boundary layer at the front location, which is capped by the pycnocline. As the tidal level increases, tide-induced vertical mixing leads to plume structures that occupy the entire water column.
